questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between speed and velocity?
options: Speed is always faster than velocity
Velocity includes direction, speed does not
Speed is measured in m/s, velocity in km/h
Speed is for cars, velocity is for planes
questions.explanation: Speed is a scalar quantity (magnitude only), while velocity is a vector quantity (magnitude and direction). Both can be measured in the same units.

questions.question: Which of the following represents speed?
questions.explanation: Speed is a scalar quantity, so it only needs magnitude: '18 m/s'. The other options with directions represent velocity.

questions.question: A car travels 180 km in 4 hours. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time = 180 km ÷ 4 h = 45 km/h

questions.question: What is uniform velocity?
options: Velocity that remains constant in both magnitude and direction
questions.explanation: Uniform velocity means both the speed and direction remain constant over time.

questions.question: A car travels at 75 km/h for 3 hours. What total distance does it cover?
questions.explanation: Distance = speed × time = 75 km/h × 3 h = 225 km

questions.question: What are the units for both speed and velocity?
questions.explanation: Both speed and velocity are measured in units of distance per time, such as meters per second (m/s) or kilometers per hour (km/h).

questions.question: A boat moves with velocity 12 m/s East. What is its speed?
questions.explanation: Speed is the magnitude of velocity, so if velocity is 12 m/s East, the speed is 12 m/s (scalar quantity, no direction).

questions.question: What is non-uniform velocity?
options: Velocity that changes in magnitude, direction, or both
questions.explanation: Non-uniform velocity means the velocity changes - either the speed changes, the direction changes, or both change.

questions.question: A person walks 3 m/s North for 15 seconds, then 4 m/s South for 15 seconds. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance North = 3 m/s × 15 s = 45 m, Distance South = 4 m/s × 15 s = 60 m, Total distance = 45 + 60 = 105 m (scalar addition)

questions.question: What is the average velocity for the person who walked 3 m/s North for 15s then 4 m/s South for 15s?
questions.explanation: Displacement North = 45 m, Displacement South = 60 m, Net displacement = 15 m South. Total time = 30 s. Average velocity = 15 m South ÷ 30 s = 0.5 m/s South

questions.question: A car travels 80 km at 50 km/h, then another 80 km at 80 km/h. What is the average speed for the entire trip?
questions.explanation: Time for first part = 80 km ÷ 50 km/h = 1.6 h, Time for second part = 80 km ÷ 80 km/h = 1 h, Total distance = 160 km, Total time = 2.6 h, Average speed = 160 km ÷ 2.6 h = 61.5 km/h

questions.question: Which quantity is calculated as total distance divided by total time?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time. Average velocity = total displacement ÷ total time.

questions.question: A boat has velocity 6 m/s East. A person walks on the boat with velocity 3 m/s East. What is the person's velocity relative to the water?
questions.explanation: When velocities are in the same direction, they add: 6 m/s East + 3 m/s East = 9 m/s East (vector addition)

questions.question: If the person walks 3 m/s West instead of East, what is their velocity relative to the water?
questions.explanation: 6 m/s East + 3 m/s West = 3 m/s East (vector addition with opposite directions)

questions.question: What does it mean when an object has constant speed but changing velocity?
options: The object is moving in a straight line
The object is moving in a circle at constant speed
The object is accelerating in a straight line
questions.explanation: When an object moves in a circle at constant speed, the speed is constant but the velocity changes because the direction is constantly changing.

questions.question: A train travels 450 meters in 25 seconds. What is its average speed in m/s?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time = 450 m ÷ 25 s = 18 m/s

questions.question: Which of the following describes uniform velocity?
options: A car going around a curve at constant speed
A train moving straight at 120 km/h
questions.explanation: A train moving straight at constant speed has uniform velocity - both magnitude and direction are constant.

questions.question: A river flows at 4 m/s East. A boat moves at 6 m/s North relative to the water. What is the boat's speed relative to the shore?
questions.explanation: The velocities are perpendicular, so use Pythagoras: speed = √(4² + 6²) = √(16 + 36) = √52 ≈ 7.2 m/s

questions.question: What is the main reason average speed and average velocity can be different?
options: Distance and displacement can be different
Speed is always larger than velocity
questions.explanation: Average speed uses total distance, while average velocity uses net displacement. When the path is not straight, distance > displacement, so average speed > average velocity magnitude.

questions.question: An object moves with uniform velocity of 15 m/s East. Where will it be after 4 seconds?
questions.explanation: Displacement = velocity × time = 15 m/s East × 4 s = 60 m East
